conclusion: Understanding the problem involves two velocity-time graphs for objects A and B moving in the same direction.
Explanation of what a velocity-time graph represents with time on x-axis and velocity on y-axis.
Both objects start from time 0 and reach time t1; Object A has a higher velocity than B throughout.
There's a red line labeled 'Difference' representing the difference in velocities at a particular time.
Need to determine if the difference in velocity increases throughout the interval from 0 to t1.
In a velocity-time graph, the slope represents acceleration.
The difference in velocity is given by Difference(t) = v_A(t) - v_B(t).
The slope of the difference curve gives the difference in acceleration: a_A(t) - a_B(t).
Velocity is a function of time, so the difference in velocity is also a function of time.
To find if difference(t) is increasing, look at its derivative: difference'(t) = a_A(t) - a_B(t).
Both curves are symmetric about a vertical line in the middle, suggesting symmetric acceleration and deceleration.
Object A reaches its peak velocity before object B.
Both curves start at the origin and return to zero velocity at time t1.
Assuming both curves are parabolic, object A has a higher peak velocity and reaches it earlier.
For a parabolic velocity-time curve, acceleration is linear.
Assuming v(t) = c*t*(t - t1) gives a parabolic shape with roots at t=0 and t=t1.
